dialogues.text: Quarterly reports came in this morning -- our sales are up two point three percent -- that's in the top twenty of all of the Sheets N’ Things in the state.

dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: I‘m pretty sure moving the Primaloft comforters out front made the difference -- and we all know whose decision that was. They share a smile. Terri flips through a POTTERY BARN CATALOGUE, carefully marking items she’s interested in wi COLOR CODED POST-IT FLAGS.

dialogues.text: Sure, maybe we could trade in some of your stock options. All I‘m going to say is they're hiring at HW Menken...

dialogues.speaker: TERRI

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And when I tried it I was miserable. I need something more.,.creative. (noticing the Post-Its) Why does the lamp get a red one?

I'll stock up on everything tomorrow.

dialogues.text: Years passed. Glee was no longer a place where you went with dreams of being a star, it was a haven for outcasts. Finally, everyone has disappeared eacept for Rachel, Kurt Arty, MERCEDES, TINA, who TWITCHES and HANK -- the last o the “in crowd” still in Glee Club.

Highschool Bitch Goddess Quinn Fabray forms the top of th Cheerios! pyramid. Beads of sweat drop down their faces, over-tanned, ponytailed WOMAN stares at a stopwatch.

There was a rumor that Sue had posed for Penthouse Magazine and took horse estrogen, but that was only a rumor. The stopwatch reads 23 minutes. The pyramid trembles.

dialogues.text: There was a vacancy, and fate called on me to fill it. INT. TEACHER'S LOUNGE -- DAY --— FLASHBACK 13 Will goes to get coffee, but there’s no pot. He turns to buddy, KEN TANAKA, the history teacher/football coach.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA,
dialogues.text: (not flirty) Hey, Ken. (then, trying to be cool) Hey, Will. What's with the lattes?

Emma pulls a HANDY WIPE out of her purse, starts CLEANING table in front of her. Will watches as she meticulously scrubs her place setting, then takes her own plastic silverware, plate and cup out of her bag. She notices the stares, smiles nervously hoping they won’t talk about her OcD, then puts her LUNCH on her plate and starts eating.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA

dialogues.speaker: EMMA, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I think I can make it great again. There’s no joy in these kids. They feel invisible. That's why every ne of them has a Myspace page.

dialogues.text: Sixty bucks a month. That's what I need to keep the program up.

dialogues.text: I'm certainly not going to. We’re not talking about The Cheerios here, Will, They were on Fox Sports Net last year. When Glee Club starts bringing that kind of prestige to the school again, you can have all the money you want. Until then, sixty a month -- and you've got to use the costumes and props we already have. Oh, but we need the stools for wood shop.

One thing I knew for sure, we needed a new name. Sandy's “Rhythm Explosion” didn’t cut it. Will pops up in bed, eyes wide with excitement -- he has INT. dialogues.text: My dads spoiled me in the arts, I was given dance lessons, vocal lessons.,..anything to give me a competitive edge. REVEAL Little Rachel at the end, grinning manically and t dancing like a fiend. INT. RACHEL’S ROOM -- DAY —- FLASHBACK 23 Rachel is at her computer.

dialogues.text: I try to post a MySpace video every day, just to keep my talent alive and growing. WHIP PAN to reveal Rachel, still singing “On My Own.”

dialogues.text: Nowadays, being anonymous is worse than being peor, Fame is the most important thing in our culture now. INT. SCHOOL GYM -—— DAY 24 Quinn, Santana and the cheerleaders are huddled over a la with wireless, dying laughing at Rachel’s MySpace entry.

dialogues.text: And if there's one thing I've learned, it's that no one is gonna just hand it to you. INT, RACHEL'S ROOM —- DAY —- FLASHBACK 25 Back to the computer. Rachel, biting her lip, scrolls thr her feedback, all nasty notes from The Cheerios. “Why don't you die already?” “Your videos make me want to kill my entire family.” “Please get sterilized.” Rachel i hurt. dialogues.text: I’m not wearing this,

dialogues.text: Those costumes are good luck. The “93 team took nationals wearing them.

dialogues.text: I know -- I can still smell them. Whoever wore this dress before me clearly had the stink ass. I want a new costume.

dialogues.text: The Cheerios are running through a routine. They could op the Olympics. They finish, breathing hard, hoping for pra

dialogues.text: That's sloppy! You're sloppy babies! They wilt. PAN UP, to find Rachel, sitting high up in the Stands. She stares down longingly at The Cheerios...the popular ones. REVEAL Will climbing up. He sits next to he

dialogues.text: "Pilot" Blue Revisions 10/21/08 16.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You’re the best kid in there, Rachel -- but that comes with a price. The other kids are looking to you for guidance. You've got to be more optimistic.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You sound like my dads -- “power of positive thinking” and all of that. I know I'm just a sophomore but I ean feel the clock ticking away. Tf don't want to leave high school with nothing to show for it.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You get great grades, you're 24 fantastic singer...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Everybody hates me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And you think Glee Club is going ta change that?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Being great at something is going to change it. Being part of something special...makes you special. Right? WILL. What if I give you all the solos?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Glee club isn’t about solos -- it's about duets, it's a team sport. I need a male lead who can keep up with me vocally. -—

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Maybe if I tutor Arty a little...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Shue, I really appreciate what you're trying to do, but if you can’t get me what I need, I'm sorry...I'm not going to make a fool of myself. I can’t keep wasting my time with Glee -- it hurts too much.  “Pilot” Blue Revisions 10/21/06 17. Will ponders his next move when A WHISTLE BLASTS.

dialogues.speaker: KEN TANAKA
dialogues.text: Schuester! Figgins wants you. 29 INT. PRINCIPAL FIGGINS’ OFFICE -- DAY 29

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: But we just started rehearsals.

dialogues.speaker: FIGGINS
dialogues.text: My hands are tied, Shue, I need the auditorium. Alcoholics Anonymous wants to rent it out for their afternoon meetings. Lots of drunks in this town, and they're paying me ten bucks a head.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Give me two months. If we show at Regionals, Glee stays, if not the bar's open in the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: FIGGINS
dialogues.text: What is it with you and this club, Will? I like to see passion in my teachers, but this is bordering on obsession. It's time to let it go, You've only got five kids -- one of them’s a cripple.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Then I guess you've got nothing to worry about,

dialogues.speaker: FIGGINS
dialogues.text: Fine, two months -- but you're running detention for free to make it up to me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Deal. Off Will, having no idea how he’s going to pull this off

dialogues.text: 30 INT. SHEETS N’ THINGS -— DAY 30 Terri is showing HOWARD how to fold a FITTED SHEET.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: You've got to stick your hands in the corners like this, see? HOWARD. I can‘t do it. I'm dyslexic. Maybe I should just stick to towels and washcloths.

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: If you can't fold a fitted sheet you can’t work at Sheets N’ Things, Howard.

dialogues.speaker: INTERCOM VOICE
dialogues.text: Associate to returns.

Making money? Being upwardly mobile? I love her, but we've...grown apart. We’ve just got to get back on the same page... The house lights flash on and off. Showtime.  61
